abstract: The United States should start running a federal budget surplus, and consider refinancing some of its existing debt to China.
snippet: The United States should start running a federal budget surplus, and consider refinancing some of its existing debt to China.
lead_paragraph: Cheap money from China helped create the debt-fueled investment bubble that has now burst spectacularly. Beijing’s policy of keeping its currency artificially low allowed it to rack up huge trade surpluses  cash that was recycled to help Americans live beyond their means. The Group of 20 leaders gathering in London ought to be focusing on preventing such imbalances in the future.

headline.main: Fixing Imbalances for the Long Run

lead_paragraph: During the recent economic boom, rents in the priciest Manhattan office towers skyrocketed. A similar trend occurred in the city’s less well-heeled office buildings, known in real estate jargon as Class B buildings. But today, vacancies are rising and rents are falling sharply in both classes of buildings, especially in Midtown.

abstract: The pioneer of instant photography was sold in an auction for $59.1 million to the private equity firm Patriarch Partners, an investor in the Arizona Iced Tea brand and the map maker Rand McNally.
snippet: The pioneer of instant photography was sold in an auction for $59.1 million to the private equity firm Patriarch Partners, an investor in the Arizona Iced Tea brand and the map maker Rand McNally.
lead_paragraph: Polaroid, the pioneer of instant photography, was sold in an auction for $59.1 million to the private equity firm Patriarch Partners, an investor in the Arizona Iced Tea brand and the map maker Rand McNally. Patriarch’s offer for assets, including most of Polaroid’s intellectual-property rights, is subject to approval by a judge in United States Bankruptcy Court in St. Paul. “We intend to continue rebuilding the brand of this great American company on a worldwide scale and to re-establish Polaroid as a globally acknowledged innovator,” Lynn Tilton, chief executive of Patriarch, said.

headline.main: Private Equity Group Buys Polaroid for $59 Million

The company, which is planning to merge with the concert promoter Live Nation, informed brokers who use its TicketsNow resale service of the subpoenas in an e-mail message. The message was posted on TicketNews.com, a site owned by a broker, and was confirmed by Ticketmaster.

lead_paragraph: Google must defend itself against claims that its sponsored links on search results violated the trademark rights of the Rescuecom Corporation, an appeals court said. Rescuecom, a computer services company, sued in 2004 over the use of its company name as a “keyword” in the AdWords program used by Google. Advertisers can buy placement on a search-results page based on the use of such keywords, and in some cases the “sponsored links” are shown at the top of the results.

abstract: An obituary last Saturday about Irving R. Levine, the longtime NBC television news correspondent, attributed an erroneous distinction to his network. Although NBC made Mr. Levine its first full-time reporter covering economic news, in 1971, ABC News appointed Louis Rukeyser its economics editor in 1968. Mr. Levine’s work was not the first time a network had focused full-time on economics coverage.

abstract: Who says “Who steals my purse steals trash”?
snippet: Who says “Who steals my purse steals trash”?
lead_paragraph: Up until the last hundred years or so, most humans on the planet could mark the passage of time by the monthly progression of the lunar cycle. Without electricity to turn night into day, the most obvious fact of life after sunset was the size and shape of the moon. Today, most of us live in cities. With the combination of air pollution and light pollution, the average modern person couldn’t even tell you the phase of the moon today. It’s waxing, near full.

headline.main: Speaking With Lofty Language

abstract: The Italian energy company sold a 20 percent stake in the Russian oil giant Gazprom Neft for $4.1 billion.
snippet: The Italian energy company sold a 20 percent stake in the Russian oil giant Gazprom Neft for $4.1 billion.
lead_paragraph: The Italian energy company Eni sold a 20 percent stake in the Russian oil giant Gazprom Neft for $4.1 billion, in the largest of about a dozen deals announced at a Russian-Italian business forum. The sale was the final unwinding of a long-abandoned merger plan between the Russian oil companies Yukos and Sibneft, the company now called Gazprom Neft. Yukos had bought the shares in Sibneft in anticipation of that merger. When Yukos was forced into bankruptcy, it was still holding the shares in what had become the oil arm of Gazprom. Eni bought the stake at a Yukos bankruptcy auction two years ago with the understanding they would be sold to Gazprom. Gazprom has now consolidated nearly all the shares in Gazprom Neft, owning 95.68 percent of the company.

headline.main: Russia: Eni Sells Gazprom Stake
headline.print_headline: RUSSIA: ENI SELLS GAZPROM STAKE

abstract: Wal-Mart de México said sales at stores open at least a year fell 1.1 percent in March.
snippet: Wal-Mart de México said sales at stores open at least a year fell 1.1 percent in March.
lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart de México said sales at stores open at least a year fell 1.1 percent in March. Same-store sales fell in part because March had one fewer Saturday than last year and Easter, which was in March in 2008, is in April this year, the company said in a statement. Total revenue last month rose 5.9 percent to 21 billion pesos ($1.56 billion), the company, based in Mexico City, said. The number of transactions fell 0.5 percent on a comparable-store basis, said the company, known as Walmex. The value of the average transaction dropped 0.6 percent. Wal-Mart Stores owns two-thirds of Walmex.

headline.main: Mexico: March Walmex Sales Fall
headline.print_headline: MEXICO: MARCH WALMEX SALES FALL

headline.main: Ireland’s Emergency Budget Includes Help for Banks

abstract: Nobel Prize-winning economists like Joseph E. Stiglitz and Paul Krugman, also a New York Times columnist, have been harshly critical of the Treasury’s public-private investment program (or P-Pip, for short) to remove toxic assets from banks’ balance sheets. Broadly speaking, these economists worry that the taxpayers are getting a raw deal because they are taking most of the risk and receiving little benefit from the government program.

abstract: Panic is retreating, at least at the S.E.C. There was a lot of reasoned discussion today as the commission sought comment on restrictions on short-selling.
snippet: Panic is retreating, at least at the S.E.C. There was a lot of reasoned discussion today as the commission sought comment on restrictions on short-selling.
lead_paragraph: The S.E.C. is putting out for comment a bunch of possible short-selling restrictions today. There are several variations on two ideas. First is an uptick rule, like one we used to have, that bars short-selling at a price lower than the last different price. Second is some type of circuit breaker, like barring further short sales of a particular stock on a day that stock has fallen 10 percent.

headline.main: Nail the Shorts?

lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — On Nov. 29, 2006, Ford Motor made a surprising pitch to the nation’s biggest banks. In a packed ballroom at a New York hotel, Ford’s chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, said he would mortgage all the company’s assets for billions of dollars in loans to finance an overhaul of the troubled automaker. Although the economy was healthy then, Mr. Mulally said the money would give Ford “a cushion to protect for a recession or other unexpected event.”

headline.main: Choosing Its Own Path, Ford Stayed Independent
headline.print_headline: Right on the Money

abstract: The free Adobe Reader software has a Read Aloud feature that can audibly recite the contents of many PDF files.
snippet: The free Adobe Reader software has a Read Aloud feature that can audibly recite the contents of many PDF files.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need an Amazon Kindle 2 to have a mechanical box read documents out loud. Although its main function is to display PDF files, the free Adobe Reader software (www.adobe.com/products/reader) has a Read Aloud feature that can audibly recite the contents of many PDF files. To hear it for yourself, open a PDF file, go to the View menu and activate the feature from the Read Out Loud submenu. While copy-protected e-books may not be compatible with Read Out Loud, it is fine for works in the public domain, like books in PDF files from Project Gutenberg (gutenberg.us), academic papers and other PDF files.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Let Your Documents Do the Talking

abstract: United Airlines received permission to delay until June 2010 the start of flights between San Francisco and Guangzhou, China, because of a drop in travel demand.
snippet: United Airlines received permission to delay until June 2010 the start of flights between San Francisco and Guangzhou, China, because of a drop in travel demand.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines, the operating unit of the UAL Corporation, received permission from the United States Transportation Department to delay until June 2010 the start of flights between San Francisco and Guangzhou, China, because of a drop in travel demand. The one-year postponement is the second by the airline for the route, which originally was to have begun in June 2008. United, which is based in Chicago, joins Northwest Airlines, American Airlines and US Airways Group in pushing back the start of flights between the United States and China in the last year.

headline.main: China: Delay in Flight Route
headline.print_headline: CHINA: DELAY IN FLIGHT ROUTE

abstract: Canada filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization asking South Korea to lift a ban on Canadian beef exports imposed during an outbreak of mad cow disease.
snippet: Canada filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization asking South Korea to lift a ban on Canadian beef exports imposed during an outbreak of mad cow disease.
lead_paragraph: Canada filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization asking South Korea to lift a ban on Canadian beef exports imposed during an outbreak of mad cow disease. Canada has asked for a consultation on the case, and if that fails, a dispute settlement panel may be needed, Stockwell Day, the trade minister, said in a statement from Ottawa. Before the ban was imposed in 2003, South Korea was the one of the largest markets for Canadian beef, with exports valued at $50 million Canadian dollars ($41 million) a year. South Korea last June reopened its market to beef from the United States.

headline.main: Canada: Seeks End to Beef Ban
headline.print_headline: CANADA: SEEKS END TO BEEF BAN

lead_paragraph: The World Bank approved a $1.5 billion loan to Mexico to support health and education programs for poor children. The Mexican government will use the money to help residents under the Oportunidades project, which gives cash to families who agree to keep their children in school and provide them with health care, the bank said in an e-mailed statement.

headline.main: Mexico: World Bank Loan
headline.print_headline: MEXICO: WORLD BANK LOAN

abstract: American farmers are feeling the effects of the global economic slump as demand for U.S. food exports falls.
snippet: American farmers are feeling the effects of the global economic slump as demand for U.S. food exports falls.
lead_paragraph: Only a year ago, all the stars appeared to be aligned for American farm exports. China and other developing countries were fattening up growing herds of cattle on American corn, and they were importing record amounts of foods to meet the appetite of their expanding middle classes. A drought in Australia meant a shortage of wheat on world markets. The price of dairy products soared across the globe because of shortages.

headline.main: Exports Fall, and It’s Felt on the Farm
headline.print_headline: U.S. Farms Hit by Drop In Exports

lead_paragraph: Polaroid, the pioneer of instant photography, must try again to auction off its assets after failing to win the approval of Judge Gregory F. Kishel of United States Bankruptcy Court for a $56.3 million sale. Last week, the private equity firm Patriarch Partners won an auction for the assets with a bid of $59.1 million. Judge Kishel reopened the auction this week, citing complaints over the procedures. Patriarch lost, and Polaroid sought court approval to sell itself to a joint venture of two liquidation companies, Hilco Consumer Capital and Gordon Brothers Brands.

headline.main: New Auction Scheduled to Sell Polaroid’s Assets

abstract: Cape Fear Bank of Wilmington, N.C., and New Frontier Bank in Greeley, Colo., were closed by regulators, bringing the total number of United States bank failures this year to 23.
snippet: Cape Fear Bank of Wilmington, N.C., and New Frontier Bank in Greeley, Colo., were closed by regulators, bringing the total number of United States bank failures this year to 23.
lead_paragraph: Cape Fear Bank of Wilmington, N.C., and New Frontier Bank in Greeley, Colo., were closed by regulators, bringing the total number of United States bank failures this year to 23. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was named receiver of Cape Fear. First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Charleston in South Carolina will assume the deposits, and Cape Fear’s eight branches will open on Monday as First Federal offices, the F.D.I.C. said. In New Frontier’s case, the F.D.I.C. arranged for Bank of the West in San Francisco to operate a new bank, Deposit Insurance National Bank of Greeley, and two branches for the next 30 days while the bank is wound down. Depositors will have 30 days to find a new bank for their accounts.

headline.main: Regulators Close 2 Banks, Bringing Total for Year to 23

abstract: Qantas Airways slashed its full-year profit forecast and said it would cut jobs and ground aircraft to cope with a slump in international travel.
snippet: Qantas Airways slashed its full-year profit forecast and said it would cut jobs and ground aircraft to cope with a slump in international travel.
lead_paragraph: Qantas Airways slashed its full-year profit forecast and said it would cut jobs and ground aircraft to cope with a slump in international travel. The airline’s profit before tax this fiscal year probably will be $100 million Australian dollars ($73 million) to $200 million Australian dollars. That is down from a previous estimate of $500 million Australian dollars. Qantas plans 1,250 full-time job cuts and to eliminate 500 management positions, adding to staff reductions announced earlier. “Market conditions have deteriorated, especially in our international business," its chief executive, Alan Joyce, said in a statement. The airline cut its flying capacity by 5 percent and said it would defer orders for four A380 and 12 737-800 aircraft.

headline.main: Australia: Qantas Cuts Forecast

abstract: The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, or ICBC, said it was now the world’s largest bank by deposits after clients invested another 950 billion yuan ($140 billion) in the first quarter. Deposits rose to 8.9 trillion yuan as of March 31; including deposits from financial companies, the amount was 9.78 trillion yuan ($1.43 trillion), the bank said in a statement. ICBC overtook JPMorgan Chase and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group of Japan, according to the statement. JPMorgan had $1 trillion in deposits at the end of 2008, while the Japanese lender held $1.29 trillion as of March 31, 2008, according to Bloomberg data.

Part of the magic of crosswords is that everyone comes to each puzzle with unique personal life experiences. lead_paragraph: TIP OF THE WEEK Spring is in the air, and so is baseball season. For fans wanting to keep the game close, the Baseball Toolbar and Theme add-on for Firefox converts the browser window into a baseball news portal, complete with a shortcut button to a any team’s Web site, streaming headlines in the toolbar and video clips in the side panel. The browser’s Home button is even converted to an icon of home plate. The Baseball Toolbar and Theme is available at https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/8848 and can be removed from the Add-ons box in the Firefox Tools menu when the season is over.

headline.main: Smoothing Out Hulu Streams

abstract: The country’s millionaires average 39 years old, and 48 percent are concentrated in Beijing, Shanghai and the southern province of Guangdong.
snippet: The country’s millionaires average 39 years old, and 48 percent are concentrated in Beijing, Shanghai and the southern province of Guangdong.
lead_paragraph: China has 825,000 people with net worth of 10 million yuan ($1.5 million) and many have not been affected by the financial crisis, according to research from Hurun Report, which compiles an annual list of China’s richest people. The country’s millionaires average 39 years old, and 48 percent are concentrated in Beijing, Shanghai and the southern province of Guangdong, near Hong Kong, the report found. As many as 51,000 people have more than 100 million yuan ($14.7 million) in personal wealth, it said. Its estimate is based on investment and spending indicators including property and car purchases, and on income distribution analysis.

headline.main: China: Estimate of Millionaires Grows
headline.print_headline: China: Estimate of Millionaires Grows

abstract: The largest shareholder of UTS Energy said it would not support a sweetened takeover offer from Total of France.
snippet: The largest shareholder of UTS Energy said it would not support a sweetened takeover offer from Total of France.
lead_paragraph: The largest shareholder of UTS Energy said it would not support a sweetened takeover offer from Total of France. West Face Capital, a fund manager based in Toronto, owns more than 12 percent of UTS’s stock and said the bid for 830 million Canadian dollars ($689 million) was inadequate. Total’s bid does not properly take into account the value of the Canadian company’s cash and other assets, said Gregory Boland, chief executive at West Face Capital. Total, which made its first proposal to buy UTS in January, increased the bid by 35 percent this week. UTS is worth hundreds of millions more than Total is offering, William Roach, UTS’s chief executive, said in an interview on Monday.

headline.main: Canada: Total Offer Is Criticized
headline.print_headline: CANADA: TOTAL OFFER IS CRITICIZED

abstract: EBay offered to buy Gmarket, an e-commerce marketplace in South Korea, for $1.2 billion as part of its plans to expand overseas.
snippet: EBay offered to buy Gmarket, an e-commerce marketplace in South Korea, for $1.2 billion as part of its plans to expand overseas.
lead_paragraph: EBay offered to buy Gmarket, an e-commerce marketplace in South Korea, for $1.2 billion as part of its plans to expand overseas. The Interpark Corporation of South Korea said in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it sold 14.6 million shares of Gmarket to eBay for $350 million. After the deals close, eBay will own 67 percent of Gmarket. EBay will combine Gmarket’s operations with Internet Auction Company, a South Korean company it already owns. EBay said in August it was considering buying a minority stake in Seoul-based Gmarket. In September, it received approval from the Korea Fair Trade Commission to buy the company’s shares.

headline.main: South Korea: Ebay to Buy Site

lead_paragraph: Corey Rubin uses every letter of the alphabet in this Friday crossword with several unusual words and phrases. Sixteen answers make their debut, including FENWAY, just in time for ball season, and the verbified eponym MIRANDIZE meaning “Read rights to.” To me, the oddest debut was DAY-PEEP, a poetic way to refer to the “Crack of dawn.” Apparently Milton used it. And ladies, if you’re looking for “The perfect match,” you can find MR. RIGHT in the grid for the first time at 32 Down.

abstract: For now, the best one can say is that China is still merely the least-sick patient on the ward.
snippet: For now, the best one can say is that China is still merely the least-sick patient on the ward.
lead_paragraph: China just reported that it has had the lowest quarterly increase in its economy since 1992. That’s not good news — but it’s not as bad as it sounds. Certainly, the 6.1 percent rise still shames the rest of the world — Singapore’s economy has just shrunk twice as fast as China’s grew. More important, there are signs that Premier Wen Jiabao’s $585 billion stimulus is taking effect. The problem now isn’t the efficacy of the medicine but the severity of the side effects.

headline.main: Signs of Health Stirring in China
headline.print_headline: Signs of Health Stirring in China

The total equals the number of banks shuttered in all of last year, as the recession drives up unemployment and home foreclosures. lead_paragraph: FOR years, portable computers were second-class citizens in the Republic of Computing. These were the auxiliary machines, adjuncts to the muscle machines on or below the desk. They were expensive, underpowered and, in the early years, much too large for anyone then to call them “laptops” or “notebooks.” In 1983, the Compaq Portable weighed 28 pounds, more than enough to set one’s shoulder throbbing halfway down an airport concourse; it cost $2,995 for one floppy-drive or $3,950 for two.

abstract: The biggest thing in mergers and acquisitions this month is Oracle’s $7.4 billion deal for Sun Microsystems. So, I was happy to see that Sun filed its agreement to be acquired by Oracle on Monday evening rather than waiting the full four business days allowed under the Securities and Exchange Commission’s Form 8-K rules. I would like to think they did so out of solicitude for Sun shareholders, but more likely it was done in order to notify any other third-party bidders of the deal protection devices that were included.
lead_paragraph: The biggest thing in mergers and acquisitions this month is Oracle’s $7.4 billion deal for Sun Microsystems. So, I was happy to see that Sun filed its agreement to be acquired by Oracle on Monday evening rather than waiting the full four business days allowed under the Securities and Exchange Commission’s Form 8-K rules. I would like to think they did so out of solicitude for Sun shareholders, but more likely it was done in order to notify any other third-party bidders of the deal protection devices that were included.

lead_paragraph: Takeover lawyers are continuing to explore their options in structuring transactions. lead_paragraph: Death and disability are two of the most difficult things for a family to discuss. But insuring against both is an important part of safeguarding a family’s future. While most families have some form of life insurance, usually purchased at marriage or with the birth of children, disability insurance is not a given. But if one or both spouses become disabled during their working life, not having it is a far greater risk to family solvency. This is where disability insurance is important. This primer will examine the basics of both types of insurance.

For one thing, it's the second Micro Four Thirds camera -- a format intended to place an S.L.R.-sized sensor (for spectacular photos) into a smaller body.

headline.main: Panasonic’s Lumix GH1: The Footnotes
headline.kicker: From the Desk of David Pogue
